trial_identification.studytitle: The Managing Anger Trial: Examining the efficacy of a treatment for anger for serving Australian Defence members
trial_identification.scientifictitle: In Defence members with problematic anger in the context of Posttraumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD), is a novel anger treatment effective in reducing the symptoms of anger

interventions.interventions: A novel anger focused intervention for Defence members who are also experiencing PTSD has been developed. This structured, Cognitive Behavioural Therapy (CBT) -based treatment is delivered by Defence psychologists in one-on-one sessions. One hour sessions are delivered once a week, for a period of 12 weeks.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Anger as assessed by the STAXI-2, DAR-5 and NAS-PI

secondaryOutcome.outcome: PTSD as assessed by the CAPS and PCL
Alcohol use as assessed by the MINI and AUDIT
Depression as assessed by the MINI and the HADS
Anxiety as assessed by the HADS

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Identified PTSD Problematic anger Available to engage in 12 sessions of treatment
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Significant alcohol dependence/abuse Psychosis Threat to self and/or others Has engaged recently in focussed anger treatment

trial_design.concealment: This trial will be advertised to participants, and participants will volunteer to participate. Allocation will not be concealed
trial_design.statisticalmethods:
Based on preliminary data from the small number of existing studies in this area, 30 clients has been shown to be sufficient to demonstrate a moderate to large clinical effect. Sample power calculations based on treatment response from a previous trial (Moreland 2010) suggest a sample size of n=30 is required to detect a 10 point difference on mean anger scores (as measured by the STAXI-2) at follow-up, with power set at 96% and p set at 0.05. The reduction of 10 points on the STAXI in Moreland 2010 was associated with a large clinical effect size.
Frequency statistics will be used to describe the incidence of disorders within the sample. Correlation analyses will be used to examine the relationship between variables. T-tests, repeated measures multivariate analyses and hedges g effect size analyses will be used to examine treatment effects.

ethicsAndSummary.summary:
The aim of this study is to evaluate the efficacy of a novel treatment for problematic anger in Defence members who are also experiencing PTSD.
It is hypothesised that the novel anger focused intervention for Defence members will result in the primary outcome of improved (reduced levels of) anger. Secondary outcomes which may be hypothesised include improved outcomes in associated mental symptomatology including depression, anxiety, alcohol use and symptoms of posttraumatic stress.
